newsitem.title: USA: U.S. Justice Dept. announces Columbia/HCA charges.
newsitem.headline: U.S. Justice Dept. announces Columbia/HCA charges.

text.p: A federal grand jury has indicted three executives at Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp. on charges of conspiracy and fraud, the Justice Department said Wednesday, the first criminal charges stemming from its probe of the nation's largest for-profit hospital chain.

The federal grand jury in Florida indicted the executives on five counts alleging conspiracy to submit false cost reports under U.S. heath care programmes and with making false statements, the department said.
"This indictment ... represents the first phase of the government's ongoing investigation" of Columbia, U.S. Attorney Charles Wilson in Florida said in a statement.

Indicted were Jay Jarrell, chief executive of Columbia's southwest Florida division; Michael Neeb, chief financial officer of its northern Florida division, and Robert Whiteside, director of reimbursememt at its Nashville headquarters.

They were charged with conspiring to submit false costs reports under Medicare and the military's Civilian Health and Medical Programme on behalf of Fawcett Memorial Hospital in Port Charlotte, Fla., from 1986 until June. The indictment was returned June 25 but made public Wednesday.
Each defendant faces up to 25 years in prison and fines up to $1.25 million if convicted.
